description:
Set in the future Kei and Yuri are Trouble Consultants for The 3WA. Code Named "Lovely Angels", but, they are known throughout the galaxy as The Dirty Pair. They always solve their case, but, not without causing collateral damage and mayhem.

(Source: Anime News Network)

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Tomboy
tags.description: Features a girl who exhibits characteristics or behaviors considered in many cultures to be typical of boys.

tags.name: Police
tags.description: Centers around the life and activities of law enforcement officers.

tags.name: Cyberpunk
tags.description: Set in a future of advanced technological and scientific achievements that have resulted in social disorder.

tags.name: Cult
tags.description: Features a social group with unorthodox religious, spiritual, or philosophical beliefs and practices.

tags.name: Drugs
tags.description: Prominently features the usage of drugs such as opioids, stimulants, hallucinogens etc.

tags.name: Wrestling
tags.description: Centers around the sport of wrestling.

node.description: Birthplace: Tokyo, Japan Website (artist page) Oomori Toshiyuki is a Japanese composer, arranger, pianist and musician.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Kadutaka_nue)

Kazutaka Miyatake is a visual artist and anime designer known for the mechanical design of the Macross TV series and a number of its continuations from Studio Nue, of which he is a founding member. He has also contributed to the mecha design of other series such as Mobile Suit Gundam SEED Destiny.

Kazutaka Miyatake has designed the spaceships of several famous anime series. His attention to detail and mechanical realism have made his designs still admired upon and used in anime series and related products after several years of their initial appearance.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kenokun)

Kouhei attended Tokyo National University of Fine Arts and Music (Music Faculty, Composition Department), studying under Tomojirou Ikenouchi and other professors. He worked for three consecutive years at Victor Music Industries after he graduated from the University. He attended Berklee College of Music for two years after he left Victor Music Industries. After returning to Japan, Kouhei started his activities as a composer.

Though Kouhei had been playing at the hotel at first, he was requested to compose an insert song for "Arcadia of My Youth: Endless Orbit SSX", a 1982 TV anime, and it became his first work as a composer. Afterwards, he handled some more compositions of insert songs, this time for the Super Sentai series and he also did the composition of the background music for a TV anime, Konpora Kid, in 1985.

Notably, the score for [Top wo Nerae! Gunbuster](https://anilist.co/anime/949/) made his name and talent very famous among anime fans, and is recognized as one of his most important works. He also handled the composition of [Top wo Nerae 2! Diebuster](https://anilist.co/anime/1002/) and showed a peculiar arrangement, which he added to his previous 17-year-old work. Another of his most important work is often said to be [Yuusha-Ou GaoGaiGar](https://anilist.co/anime/890/), and the [sequel](https://anilist.co/anime/1382/) following it.

In 2002, he won the first Tokyo Anime Award for Best Music for his work on [Overman King Gainer](https://anilist.co/anime/1792/).

__Real Name:__ Kimiyoshi Takekawa (竹川公訓)  

Haruka Takachiho is a Japanese science fiction author and founder of [Studio Nue](https://anilist.co/studio/199/Studio-Nue). Takachiho is best known as the creator of Crusher Joe, Dirty Pair and Dirty Pair Flash.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/8tabe5817) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katsuyoshi_Yatabe) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/谷田部勝義)

Yatabe Katsuyoshi is a Japanese screenwriter and director.     

After graduating he joined the Department of Arts at Nihon Daigaku in 1975. In 1978 he joined Ad Cosmo but felt that as subcontractor there would be no real productions done and thus went on to join Sunrise in 1979. There he learned under [Tomino Yoshiyuki](https://anilist.co/staff/97337) and [Takahashi Ryousuke](https://anilist.co/staff/100957) before becoming freelancer.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%98%9F%E5%B1%B1%E5%8D%9A%E4%B9%8B)

Hiroyuki Hoshiyama was a renown screenwriter. He started his career in [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/) in 1967, but left it later in 1973 and worked as a freelancer until his passing.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/土器手司)

A veteran animator best known for his involvement in the [Dirty Pair](https://anilist.co/anime/424/) franchise during the '80s, as well as the adaptations of [Rumiko Takahashi](https://anilist.co/staff/96891/)'s works. His skills were first recognized by [Yasuhiko Yoshikazu](https://anilist.co/staff/97220/) during the production of [Giant Gorg](https://anilist.co/anime/3327/), who then put him in charge of supervising three of the episodes. He has been involved with numerous of [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/)'s production's ever since.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/土器手司)

A veteran animator best known for his involvement in the [Dirty Pair](https://anilist.co/anime/424/) franchise during the '80s, as well as the adaptations of [Rumiko Takahashi](https://anilist.co/staff/96891/)'s works. A veteran animator best known for his involvement in the [Dirty Pair](https://anilist.co/anime/424/) franchise during the '80s, as well as the adaptations of [Rumiko Takahashi](https://anilist.co/staff/96891/)'s works. His skills were first recognized by [Yasuhiko Yoshikazu](https://anilist.co/staff/97220/) during the production of [Giant Gorg](https://anilist.co/anime/3327/), who then put him in charge of supervising three of the episodes. He has been involved with numerous of [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/)'s production's ever since.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/土器手司)

A veteran animator best known for his involvement in the [Dirty Pair](https://anilist.co/anime/424/) franchise during the '80s, as well as the adaptations of [Rumiko Takahashi](https://anilist.co/staff/96891/)'s works. His skills were first recognized by [Yasuhiko Yoshikazu](https://anilist.co/staff/97220/) during the production of [Giant Gorg](https://anilist.co/anime/3327/), who then put him in charge of supervising three of the episodes. He has been involved with numerous of [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/)'s production's ever since.
Handles special effects.

Most known for directing critically and commercially successful series, [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/) and [Samurai Champloo](https://anilist.co/anime/205/).

He is noted for blending together multiple genres in his anime. For example, in Cowboy Bebop, classic cowboy western mixes with '60s/'70s New York City film noir, jazz/blues music, Hong Kong action movies, and to top it off the series is set in space. In his later work, Samurai Champloo, he unites the cultures of Okinawa, hip hop, modern-day Japan, and chanbara.
[Official Website](http://www.keiko-aso.com) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/keiko_aso) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/麻生圭子)
Wakakusa Kei is a composer and arranger.  His real name is Saitou Tooru (斉藤 徹).
[Website](http://mermaid-co.jp/nakazaki/)
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/和泉常寛)
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/takama2_shinji) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/高松信司)
He is a director who belonged formerly to Studio Z, Studio Number One, Tatsunoko Pro and is now affiliated with Production I.G.

__Kenji Yamamoto__ is a Japanese music composer and arranger who has been responsible for producing and composing soundtracks, including opening and ending sequence themes for various anime, tokusatsu and video game projects in the '80s, '90s, and '00s. Most notably, he has worked on soundtracks of various Dragon Ball video games.

Yamamoto has also composed background music for Dragon Ball Z Kai, a revamped version of the anime series Dragon Ball Z. On March 9, 2011, Toei Animation publicly acknowledged that many of Yamamoto's musical works for the series infringed upon unidentified third-party copyrights.

Father of __[Kanon Yamamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/147833)__, better known as __cAnON.__.

(Source: [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenji_Yamamoto_(composer,_born_1958%29))

[Blog](http://aminon.asablo.jp/blog/) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E3%82%A2%E3%83%9F%E3%83%8E%E3%83%86%E3%83%84%E3%83%AD%E3%83%BC) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tetsur%C5%8D_Amino)

Tetsurou Amino is a Japanese director, screenwriter and storyboard artist.

In 1988, he started using his name in katakana.
[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/ste7en_foster/) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/foster.steven)

John Ledford is an entrepreneur and leader in the North American anime industry. In 1992, he founded A.D. Vision (ADV), paving the way for other businesses and the exponential growth anime has had within North America. With ADV's success, Ledford turned his sights to making the imaginative world of anime even more accessible with Anime Network's founding, North America’s first cable TV network dedicated to anime. He later partnered with Kadokawa Publishing and began Newtype USA with translated Japanese content and exclusive U.S. material related to all things anime, manga, and model reviews. This endeavor expanded into ADV Manga, which obtained licensing and publishing rights for hundreds of Japanese manga and Korean manhwa.

In 2008, Ledford founded a new anime-focused company called Sentai Filmworks (Sentai). Since its founding, Sentai provides thousands of hours of content across traditional and digital platforms. Sentai’s dedication to bringing captivating stories, including acclaimed titles such as Grave of the Fireflies, Ninja Scroll, and High School of the Dead to audiences, is ongoing.

Ledford’s most recent success is with the 2017 founding of the streaming service HIDIVE. Since launching, HIDIVE is now available via a web browser, mobile devices, gaming platforms, and more. HIDIVE offers new simulcasts every season, an ever-growing collection of dubs, and exclusive titles. The service features DUBCAST SM editions, early access local-language dubs of simulcasts directly produced by HIDIVE, as early as two weeks after the original Japanese broadcast.

For nearly thirty years now, Ledford continues his goal to further the expansion of anime and the Japanese culture as a whole.
